- Pair of 3s (3 of Clubs, 3 of Diamonds) - Level 1 (10 chips, 2 mult)
- Three Clubs: Jack, 4, 3 - could play as a flush if I get more
- No straight available

**Best Play Options:**

Option 1: Discard and look for Three of a Kind
I have Three of a Kind at Level 3 (70 chips, 7 mult) which is very strong. I should try to find three of a kind to maximize my scoring.
 
Option 2: Play a pair with clubs
Playing the pair of 4s gives me solid value. The 4 of Clubs triggers Onyx Agate for +7 mult, while Superposition adds +50 chips. With Popcorn's +8 mult, this nets 68 chips × 17 mult = 1,156 chips total.

That falls short of the 3000 chip target, so I need a stronger hand. Discarding to hunt for three of a kind in Clubs seems more promising—I'd want to keep the higher cards like the Jack and Ace since they could form straights with Superposition, while dropping the 5 of Spades, 8 of Diamonds, and 3 of Diamonds. With 4 hands and 4 discards remaining, I have room to search for better combinations.

Looking at what's left in the deck, there are only 2 remaining 3s and 2 remaining 4s, so completing a set with my pairs is unlikely. I'll discard the low cards that aren't building toward anything strong—the 5 of Spades and 8 of Diamonds for sure, then either the 3 of Diamonds or 4 of Spades depending on which draw feels more promising.

Actually, I should reconsider the clubs angle. If I can assemble three of a kind all in clubs, the scoring multiplies dramatically—Onyx Agate alone adds 21 mult across three cards, and combined with Popcorn and Superposition, I'm looking at around 5,400 chips, which crushes the 3,000 threshold. I already have Jack of Clubs, 4 of Clubs, and 3 of Clubs in hand, so I just need one more club to complete the hand.

Looking at what to discard, I want to prioritize keeping clubs and removing cards that don't support this strategy. The 5 of Spades and 4 of Spades are obvious cuts since I already have the 4 of Clubs. The Ace of Diamonds might be worth keeping for a potential straight with Superposition, but the 8 of Diamonds can go. I'll also drop the 3 of Diamonds to make room. That's four discards, which should give me enough new cards to find another club.

Actually, I should be more careful—I only have a limited number of discards total. Let me just swap out three cards: the 5 of Spades, 8 of Diamonds, and 3 of Diamonds. This preserves my pair of 4s and my three clubs while still giving me a chance to improve.

- Card chips: 11 + 11 = 22 chips
- Total chips: 10 + 22 = 32 chips


- Mult: 2 base + 8 (Popcorn) = 10 mult
- No clubs scored, so no Onyx Agate bonus
- Total: 32 × 10 = 320 chips

That's not enough.

**Option 2: Play Pair of 4s**
If I play 4 of Spades and 4 of Clubs:

- Card chips: 4 + 4 = 8 chips
- Total chips: 10 + 8 = 18 chips
- Mult: 2 base + 8 (Popcorn) + 7 (Onyx Agate for one Club) = 17 mult
- Total: 18 × 17 = 306 chips

Still insufficient. I need to find a way to score significantly more chips per hand, likely by building larger hands or leveraging the Superposition joker's Tarot creation mechanic.

**Option 3: Discard and look for Three of a Kind**
Three of a Kind at Level 3 offers 70 chips and 7 mult as a base. If I can form this with club cards, I'd get around 30 chips from the cards themselves, plus the Onyx Agate bonus would multiply my mult substantially—potentially reaching 21 mult or higher with all bonuses combined.

Looking at what's available in the deck, I have several opportunities to complete a three-card set. I already hold one Ace, one 3, one Jack, one 9, and one 7, with multiple copies of each still in play. The most promising paths would be drawing another Ace or completing one of the other ranks where I have cards in hand.

For my discard strategy, I should prioritize keeping cards that work toward multiple winning combinations—particularly the clubs since they could contribute to both a flush and a three-of-a-kind. Between my paired Aces and paired 4s, either would give me a strong foundation to build from.

If I discard the non-club cards (9 of Hearts, 7 of Hearts, Jack of Clubs, 3 of Clubs), I'm left with my Aces and 4s to potentially complete. But actually, the clubs deserve more consideration since Onyx Agate multiplies their value significantly. I have three clubs currently—Jack, 4, and 3—and getting a third matching club would be more valuable than a standard three-of-a-kind.

However, drawing two specific clubs from the remaining deck is unlikely. My better bet is completing one of my existing pairs into a three-of-a-kind, which gives me a solid hand while still potentially including a club for the multiplier bonus.

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
